title: Are You A Classical Or Romantic Voter?

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are the two fundamental electoral types of voters?
What is a key characteristic of romantic voters?

options.label: A
options.text: They are highly distrustful of sudden gestures and actions

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that a far better world could be just around the corner if only bold and swift action could be taken

options.label: C
options.text: They pay special attention to what can go wrong

options.label: D
options.text: They are led by a desire not to make anything worse

multiple-choice.question: How do classical voters view people?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that everyone is probably slightly better than they seem

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that everyone is probably slightly worse than they seem

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that people are inherently good

options.label: D
options.text: They believe that people are inherently evil

options.label: A
options.text: To liberate genius, strength, beauty, or benevolence

options.label: B
options.text: To try and contain human impulses, lusts, and drives

multiple-choice.question: How do romantic voters approach blame and responsibility?

options.label: A
options.text: They are hesitant to apportion blame and recognize the complexity of issues

options.label: B
options.text: They are quick to identify wrongdoers and respond accordingly

options.label: C
options.text: They believe that problems are always someone else's fault

options.label: D
options.text: They think that blame is irrelevant in politics

multiple-choice.question: What do classical voters think about the distribution of evil in society?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that evil is concentrated in certain groups or classes

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that evil is proportionately distributed across all groups and classes

options.label: C
options.text: They think that evil is nonexistent

options.label: D
options.text: They think that evil is only found in individuals

multiple-choice.question: How do romantic voters view the role of individuals in shaping history?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that talented individuals can take destiny into their hands and create positive change

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that individuals are powerless to shape history

options.label: C
options.text: They think that institutions are more important than individuals

options.label: D
options.text: They think that chance and circumstance are the primary drivers of history

multiple-choice.question: What do classical voters think about the importance of institutions in politics?

options.label: A
options.text: They believe that institutions are unnecessary and stifle individual creativity

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that institutions are essential for restraining individual power and containing the capacity for error

options.label: C
options.text: They think that institutions are irrelevant in modern politics

options.label: D
options.text: They think that institutions are only necessary in times of crisis

multiple-choice.question: How do romantic voters approach dissenting views?

options.label: A
options.text: They are committed to hearing and tolerating dissenting views

options.label: B
options.text: They believe that dissenting views are irrelevant and can be ignored

options.label: C
options.text: They think that dissenting views are a sign of weakness

options.label: D
options.text: They think that dissenting views are a threat to their own power

title: Can you solve the prisoner boxes riddle? - Yossi Elran

options.label: C
options.text: They have to find their instruments from ten large boxes with randomly placed instruments.

options.label: D
options.text: They need to solve a mathematical puzzle to get to their next concert.

options.label: A
options.text: They can only look inside three boxes.

options.label: B
options.text: They can look inside any five boxes but cannot touch the instruments.

options.label: C
options.text: They can only open one box at a time.

options.label: D
options.text: They have to find their instrument within a minute.

options.text: Each musician opens the box with the picture of their instrument and then opens the box with the picture of the instrument they found.

options.label: B
options.text: Each musician opens five random boxes to increase their chances.

options.label: C
options.text: Each musician opens the box with the picture of their instrument and then opens the box with the picture of a different instrument.

options.label: D
options.text: Each musician opens the box with the picture of their instrument and then stops.

options.label: A
options.text: Because each musician is essentially guessing randomly.

options.label: B
options.text: Because each musician restricts their search to the loop that contains their instrument.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: The odds of success remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: The odds of success increase significantly.

options.label: D
options.text: The odds of success approach about 30%.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It was a dance that became a worldwide craze and blurred the boundaries between groups.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a dance that was only performed by professional dancers.

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: To heal, remember, and express a common language and freedom.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: The present is a complete rejection of the past.

options.label: C
options.text: The present always contains the past, and the past shapes who we are and who we will be.

options.label: D

options.text: The nervous system uses hormones, while the endocrine system uses neurotransmitters.

options.label: B
options.text: The nervous system uses electrical signals, while the endocrine system uses chemical signals.

options.label: C
options.text: The nervous system uses slow, widespread signals, while the endocrine system uses fast, targeted signals.

options.label: D
options.text: The nervous system uses fast, targeted signals, while the endocrine system uses slow, widespread signals.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the gland that is considered the "master gland" of the endocrine system?
What is the function of the hormone thyroxine, produced by the thyroid gland?
How do hormones bind to their target cells?

options.label: B
options.text: Through chemical signals, either on the outside or inside of the cell membrane

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the pancreas in regulating blood sugar levels?
What is the name of the complex series of interactions between the hypothalamus, pituitary gland, and adrenal gland that regulates the body's stress response?
What is the function of the hormone cortisol, produced by the adrenal gland?

title: The history of the Cuban Missile Crisis - Matthew A. Jordan

multiple-choice.question: What was the 45-year period after World War II known as?
What was the failed attempt by the U.S. to overthrow Cuba's communist government in 1961 known as?
Why did Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev deploy nuclear missiles to Cuba?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the island and counteract the threat from U.S. missiles in Italy and Turkey

multiple-choice.question: What was President John F. Kennedy's initial response to the discovery of Soviet missiles in Cuba?

options.label: A
options.text: He ordered an airstrike on missile sites and invasion of the island

options.label: B
options.text: He announced a naval blockade of Cuba

options.label: C
options.text: He called for a diplomatic meeting with Khrushchev

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the Soviet submarine officer who refused to launch a nuclear torpedo, potentially saving the world from nuclear war?
What was the defense readiness level set by the U.S. Military during the Cuban Missile Crisis?
Who secretly met with Soviet Ambassador Anatoly Dobrynin to negotiate a proposal to end the crisis?
What was the proposal agreed upon by the U.S. and the Soviet Union to end the crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: The U.S. would invade Cuba and the Soviet Union would withdraw its missiles

options.label: B
options.text: The U.S. would remove its missiles from Turkey and Italy and promise not to invade Cuba in exchange for the Soviet withdrawal from Cuba

options.label: C
options.text: The Soviet Union would launch a nuclear attack on the U.S.

options.label: D
options.text: The U.S. would blockade Cuba indefinitely

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the message sent by Khrushchev on the morning of October 28, 1962?

options.label: A
options.text: The crisis escalated and nuclear war began

options.label: B
options.text: The crisis was resolved and the Soviet missiles were removed from Cuba

options.label: D
options.text: The Soviet Union launched a nuclear attack on the U.S.

multiple-choice.question: What was the lesson learned from the Cuban Missile Crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: That diplomacy is ineffective in resolving conflicts

options.label: B
options.text: That a slight communication error or split-second decision by a commander can have catastrophic consequences

options.label: D
options.text: That the U.S. and the Soviet Union are natural allies

title: How Americans got stuck with endless drug commercials

multiple-choice.question: In most countries, what is the status of TV commercials for prescription drugs?

options.label: A
options.text: They are allowed but heavily regulated.

options.label: B
options.text: They are allowed and widely practiced.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only allowed for certain types of prescription drugs.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how many prescription drug commercials air on American television every hour?
What was the stance of the American Medical Association on direct-to-consumer ads for prescription drugs?

options.label: A
options.text: They supported the ads as a way to educate patients.

options.label: B
options.text: They were neutral on the issue.

options.label: C
options.text: They called for a ban on the ads.

options.label: D
options.text: They wanted to regulate the ads more heavily.

multiple-choice.question: Before the 1980s, how did drug companies typically market their products?

options.label: B
options.text: They focused their marketing solely on doctors.

options.label: C
options.text: They used a combination of direct-to-consumer and doctor-focused marketing.

options.label: D
options.text: They did not market their products at all.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main barrier that kept prescription drug ads off TV before 1997?

options.label: A
options.text: FDA regulations requiring ads to include all information about the drug's risks and side effects.

options.label: B
options.text: The high cost of producing TV commercials.

options.label: C
options.text: The lack of interest from pharmaceutical companies.

options.label: D
options.text: The opposition from the American Medical Association.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the FDA's clarification of its regulations in 1997?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescription drug ads were banned from TV.

options.label: B
options.text: Pharmaceutical companies were required to include all information about the drug's risks and side effects in their ads.

options.label: C
options.text: The main barrier to prescription drug ads on TV was removed, and spending on ads quadrupled by 2004.

options.label: D
options.text: The FDA took no action, and the status quo remained.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the outcome of a study that tested the effect of prescription drug ads on doctor-patient interactions?

options.label: A
options.text: Doctors were less likely to prescribe medication to patients who mentioned seeing an ad.

options.label: B
options.text: Doctors were more likely to prescribe medication to patients who mentioned seeing an ad.

options.label: C
options.text: There was no significant difference in doctor behavior.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients who mentioned seeing an ad were more likely to be diagnosed with a serious condition.

multiple-choice.question: What was the concern raised by Justice William Rehnquist in his dissenting opinion on the Supreme Court's ruling on prescription drug advertising?

options.label: A
options.text: That ads would be too expensive for pharmaceutical companies to produce.

options.label: B
options.text: That ads would generate patient pressure on physicians to prescribe drugs.

options.label: C
options.text: That ads would be too regulated by the FDA.

options.label: D
options.text: That ads would not be effective in educating patients.

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the massive ad campaign for the painkiller Vioxx?

options.label: A
options.text: Millions of people with arthritis switched to Vioxx, and it was later found to be safer than older drugs.

options.label: B
options.text: Millions of people with arthritis switched to Vioxx, but it was later withdrawn from the market due to health concerns.

options.label: C
options.text: The ad campaign had no significant impact on Vioxx prescriptions.

options.label: D
options.text: Vioxx was found to be more effective than older drugs, but its ad campaign was not successful.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one potential benefit of prescription drug ads?

options.label: A
options.text: They can lead to overprescription of medication.

options.label: B
options.text: They can generate patient pressure on physicians to prescribe drugs.

options.label: C
options.text: They can educate patients about diseases and treatments, leading to better health outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: They can increase the cost of healthcare.

options.label: A
options.text: If you are spiritual, you therefore are intelligent

options.label: B
options.text: If you are intelligent, you therefore are spiritual

options.text: If you are intelligent, you therefore are not spiritual

options.label: D
options.text: If you are spiritual, you therefore are not intelligent

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A
options.text: "Out beyond ideas of wrong-doing and right-doing, there is a field. I'll meet you there."

options.label: B

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the potential outcome of "ubuntu work"?

options.label: A
options.text: Solutions to our most intractable-seeming problems will be found

options.label: B

options.label: C
